cohort.bio: While we all know just how important data is to business and the world, it can be hard to find ways to present that information in a meaningful and digestible way. I'm the kind of person that loves to understand why something is happening, why it matters, and how I can help others understand as well. My background in sales and customer service gives me the perspective of what matters to both businesses and consumers, and marrying those skills with data analytics has allowed me to communicate complex ideas and information to a variety of audiences. I love crafting a story or metaphor to help someone understand what I'm trying to convey while unraveling the real value contained within a data set. I can not only work with the data, I can present the findings and bring value to both the enterprise and the final client.
Aspiring data analyst who recognizes the power and responsibility that comes with data ownership.

cohort.reelThemIn: Data manipulator, because data is complicated enough
cohort.bio: Understanding the significance and importance of data to a business is very important. Problem solving has always been a passion of mine and with the world of big data growing exponentially it is important to have the necessary skills to dissect, communicate, and help businesses understand their data. I will use my skills to help dig into any data problem and bring necessary value to the cause.

cohort.reelThemIn: Torture the data and it will confess to anything
cohort.bio: I received an Engineering Technology degree from Middle Tennessee State University. For the past four years I have been on the Patient Accounting development team at Parallon, solving problems related to the lifecycle of patients' accounts. I have also played a part in enhancing/supporting the Patient Accounting application and providing data to the client from our relational database. Along the way, I became curious about obtaining insights from the data. This curiosity led me to Nashville Software School, where I am learning to effectively communicate my findings from analyzing data using Excel, Python, SQL, Tableau, and Power BI.

It's a bird, it's a plane, it's a data analyst! I graduated from Lipscomb University in 2017 with a degree in Business Administration, and have worked in the retirement planning industry for several years. I'm a naturally curious person with a passion for problem solving and learning, so becoming an analyst where I'm required to answer complex questions and learn new tools is my dream. I entered Nashville Software School with the goal of sharpening my tech skills and forging a new career path.

cohort.reelThemIn: Data Analyst by day, Gamer by night
cohort.bio: Growing up, I always knew I wanted to work in a field that would help people. Initially I thought the plan was to become a Financial Planner, but after some time in the financial field I decided to take a leap of faith and swap career paths into Data Analytics. To me, data analysts are not just there to explain data to business professionals, they are also there to help make decisions to better the company which, in turn, helps employees potentially earn more and be more successful in their careers.
As a Molecular biologist, I used my problem solving skills with my investigative driven logical sense in designing experiments and analyzing data. Data Analytics will be the next phase of my career.

cohort.reelThemIn: "Data is..." or "Data are..."? Who cares? I care! The Data is what the Data are!
cohort.bio: Consider the audience, if you are presenting to stickler grammar professors, use “The data are”. As our Data Analytics instructor Mary van Valkenburg is fond of saying: “The data is the data”. Data Analytics is about the unbiased examination of the cumulative “datum” and the story it brings to life. I am a stickler for data accuracy because there is responsibility in using data to influence decision making. I love to use my analytical, problem solving skills and creativity to present information in palatable ways for my audience to consume. I have experience working in positions where extracting, transforming, and reporting information were an important part of the job. Please follow the weblinks to find out more about me.

cohort.reelThemIn: Thinking critically and solving problems from the granular to the grand
cohort.bio: With 13-plus years of working with publishers and partners such as Amazon, Apple, and Google, I understand the analytical drivers needed for real world functionality. Data should be used to produce results and results should be used to produce good data.

cohort.reelThemIn: Translating data into business decisions and actions
cohort.bio: I work in financial planning and analysis and attended the Data Analytics bootcamp at Nashville Software School to acquire new programming skills in Python and SQL. My goal was to become more proficient at automating the repetitive tasks associated with month-end close and financial forecasting and create more time for strategic planning. I also wanted to strengthen my data visualization skills, learn how to tell a story with numbers, and isolate the critical facts. In my work, I have seen many capex projects falter because they were backed with more enthusiasm than analysis. Data analytics introduces a disciplined approach that helps take the emotion out of decisions, identifies the critical factors to consider and illuminates the way forward. Combining skills in data analytics with my business background will help me translate business problems into requirements that guide the design of a solution.

Data allows us to be involved in stories much larger than ourselves from the front end of a computer. As an ex-audio engineer who used to tour the country in a glorified van for a living, this is really appealing! My goal in life is to help those who need it, and while I try my best to do that on a micro-scale everyday, the potential that global data has to put that ability on a macro-scale is what excites me the most!

As a natural storyteller, I have always sensed how truth (as data) underlies good stories. Now that I am a data analyst, I have learned how to tease a cogent story out of a complex dataset, then present that story in a relatable, easy-to-digest way.

Having worked in the publishing industry for 20 years, I've seen how data can be used to drive important business decisions. It's now my turn to create these insights for stakeholders as a Junior Data Analyst.

I'm a curious person, and I've always enjoyed the process of discovering the underlying facts and patterns of a subject. I think connecting the dots between intuition and fact is one of the most fundamental and rewarding things to do. This trait has led me to pursue the field of data analytics.
Teacher-turned-Data Analyst, detail-oriented, passionate about extracting meaningful information in order to solve business problems using data.
Turning data into information and information into intelligence.

cohort.reelThemIn: I'm not a data storyteller; it's the data's story to tell. I'm just the interviewer
cohort.bio: We all wrestle with data, but wrestling is what got me into data. I picked up a copy of Freakonomics in 2004, and the book's exposé on corruption in sumo wrestling showed me that math could move mountains. I've pursued truth in numbers in previous chapters of my life, and the Data Analytics bootcamp at Nashville Software School has added tools to make my curiosity more actionable.

cohort.reelThemIn: Transforming data into actionable insights for better informed business decisions
cohort.bio: With a blend of technical and business backgrounds, I have always been passionate about analyzing data to help management make better informed decisions.

I love learning how details affect an outcome. When someone asks why? I enjoy figuring out the who, what, when, and where that goes into answering that seemingly basic question. Data analytics lends itself to my natural curiosity to find all the reasons and circumstances that make things the way they are today, while also allowing me to play a role in determining how to improve things for the future. I'm always trying to learn something new, whether that's in a formal classroom setting or going down rabbit holes on Stack Overflow or YouTube.

cohort.reelThemIn: In the beginning was the Data, and the Data was with God
cohort.bio: I came to data analytics with the heart and mind of a former reporter. I knew how to ask people questions, but I did not know how to ask numbers questions. In the practice of pulling meaning from a mass of information, I learned that data analytics, like journalism, is the art of knowing how to precisely ask and how to accurately report.
An engineer transforming research experience into businness by digging deep into data and interpreting data via analytical tools. Seeking small but meaningful details like a fish in the sea!
With an analytical mind and healthy dose of skepticism, I approach the problem, run a combination of analysis techniques, and deliver insights in an aesthetic and cohesive form.
I have always wanted a career that involved technology, math, and problem solving. Due to these interests, I began researching different fields and careers and landed on Data Analytics.

cohort.reelThemIn: Turning data into information that narrates an interesting story
cohort.bio: With a healthcare background, I come with an analytical mindset analyzing data problems for business solutions and growth.

Microbiologist-turned-data analyst with limitless curiosity and a penchant for problem solving and critical thinking. Analyzing data to infer insights and communicating the findings through storytelling was my favorite aspect of my microbiology career, and was ultimately the reason why I chose to pursue the field of data analytics.
